acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96 hours LC50=0.06mg/L of the crustacea (Glass Shrimp) (ECETOC TR91, 2003).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) value of 570mg/kg (RTECS (2005)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 41mg/kg (RTECS (2005)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A4 (as metal mercury and inorganic mercury compounds) by ACGIH (2001) and Group 3 (as metal mercury and inorganic mercury compounds) by IARC (1993).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and it was a metallic compound, and since an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and the absence of data on germ cell genotoxicity in vivo. Positive results (as mercury compounds) are also available in multi-generation mutagenicity tests and germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, but not used for effects assessment.

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: No data available, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen. Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1629) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
Based on the evidence of adverse developmental effects on pups (though no data are available on maternal toxicity), described in ATSDR (1999), CICAD 50 (2003) and EHC 118 (1991).
As for the reproductive toxicity of inorganic mercury compounds, refer to "ID285, Mercury Chloride (II), CAS 7487-94-7."

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): The substance causes "skin burn and pain; Corrosive to the eye/skin/respiratory tract; Oral ingestion causes corrosive effects." The substance is thus considered corrosive to the skin and classified into Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): The substance causes "skin burn and pain; Corrosive to the eye/skin/respiratory tract; Oral ingestion produces corrosive effects." The substance is thus considered corrosive to the skin and classified into Category 1A-1C. However, it should be placed in Category 1, if further subclassification is needed.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale:
Mercury is classified into "Skin Sensitizing Substance" by the ad hoc committee of the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy, and "Skin Sensitizing Substance: Group 1"* by the Japan Society for Occupational Health. These classifications, though not specifying mercury acetate, seem to include mercury compounds. Mercury acetate, which is a mercury compound, should thus cause skin sensitization. 
* There is a provision to the effect that "the category refers to the substance concerned and its compounds, but does not identify all substances causing respiratory/skin sensitization.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on the description in ICSC (J): the substance "adversely affects the central/peripheral nervous systems and kidney, may cause ataxia, sense/memory disorder, tremor, muscular weakness and kidney damage" (ICSC (J) (2000)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies: "partial hypertrophy and dilation of proximal renal tubules were initially observed, which progressed to increased dilation, hyaline cast, fibrosis and inflammation, and resulted eventually in cyst, extensive fibrosis and alterations in the glomerulus" (ATSDR (1999)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1. Classified as priority 2 by ICSC.

Note: According to CICAD 50 (2003), "renal failure, cardiovascular collapse and severe digestive organ damage are considered to be the causes of death following oral exposure to inorganic mercury. Most common findings among these are gastrointestinal tract lesion and renal failure. Exposure to inorganic mercury appears to induce nephrotic syndrome in humans."

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (kidney, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
Based on the description in ICSC (J): the substance causes "corrosion of the respiratory tract; oral ingestion causes corrosion; may adversely affect the kidney" (ICSC (J) (2000)). Classified as priority 2 by ICSC (J).

Note: According to CICAD 50 (2003), "renal failure, cardiovascular collapse and severe digestive organ damage are considered to be the causes of death following oral exposure to inorganic mercury. Most common findings among these are gastrointestinal tract lesion and renal failure. Exposure to inorganic mercury appears to induce nephrotic syndrome in humans."
